action.action-desc: Ms. Velázquez (for herself, Ms. Malliotakis, Mr. Espaillat, Mr. Tonko, Mrs. Cherfilus-McCormick, and Mrs. McIver) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Education and Workforce

form.official-title: To amend the Higher Education Act of 1965 to require institutions of higher education, as a condition of participation in programs under title IV of such Act, to establish a policy to award posthumous degrees to certain deceased students, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as Mel’s Law.

subsection.text: Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1094(a)) is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The institution certifies that the institution has established a policy to award posthumous degrees to deceased students who—

subparagraph.text: had been enrolled in a degree program at the institution;
died prior to completing such program; and
at the time of death, were in academic standing consistent with the requirements for graduation from such program, as determined by the institution.

subsection.text: Section 496(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1099b(a)) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating paragraphs (6) through (8) as paragraphs (7) through (9), respectively; and
by inserting after paragraph (5) the following:
the standards for accreditation of the agency or association do not take into consideration the number of posthumous degrees awarded by the institution to deceased students;

subsection.text: The amendments made by this Act shall take effect on the date that is 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act.
